@@ -1,21 +1,21 @@\n
'''André Okombi Salissa''' is a [[Republic of the Congo|Congolese]] politician. As a member of the ruling [[Congolese Labour Party]] (PCT), he served in the government of Congo-Brazzaville from 1997 to 2012. He was also the President-Coordinator of the [[Action Committee for the Defense of Democracy - Youth Movement]] (CADD-MJ). After his dismissal from the government, he moved into opposition, becoming the President of the [[Initiative for Democracy in Congo]] and standing as a candidate in the [[Republic of the Congo presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].

==Political career==
-Okombi Salissa was born at [[Lekana]], located in the [[Plateaux Region, Congo|Plateaux Region]] of Congo-Brazzaville;"Okombi Salissa André", ''Congo Brazzaville: Les Hommes de Pouvoir'', number 1, Africa Intelligence, 29 October 2002 {{fr icon}}. he is an ethnic [[Teke people|Téké]]. He participated in the [[Republic of the Congo Civil War|June–October 1997 civil war]] on the side of opposition leader [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]], helping to lead Sassou Nguesso's rebel [[Cobra militia]]."André Okombi Salissa (Hôtel Les Bourgeois)", ''La Lettre du Continent'', number 569, Africa Intelligence, 23 July 2009 {{fr icon}}. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103195232/http://www.africaintelligence.fr/LC-/les-rdv-du-marabout/2009/07/23/andr%C3%89-okombi-salissa-%28hotel-les-bourgeois%29,65865746-BLG |date=January 3, 2014 }}
+Okombi Salissa was born at [[Lekana]], located in the [[Plateaux Region, Congo|Plateaux Region]] of Congo-Brazzaville;"Okombi Salissa André", ''Congo Brazzaville: Les Hommes de Pouvoir'', number 1, Africa Intelligence, 29 October 2002 {{fr icon}}. he is an ethnic [[Teke people|Téké]]. He participated in the [[Republic of the Congo Civil War|June–October 1997 civil war]] on the side of opposition leader [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]], helping to lead Sassou Nguesso's rebel [[Cobra militia]]."André Okombi Salissa (Hôtel Les Bourgeois)", ''La Lettre du Continent'', number 569, Africa Intelligence, 23 July 2009 {{fr icon}}. {{wayback|url=http://www.africaintelligence.fr/LC-/les-rdv-du-marabout/2009/07/23/andr%C3%89-okombi-salissa-%28hotel-les-bourgeois%29,65865746-BLG |date=20140103195232 |df=yes}}

The Cobra militia prevailed in October 1997, capturing [[Brazzaville]] and returning Sassou Nguesso to power. As President, Sassou Nguesso appointed Okombi Salissa as Minister of Technical and Vocational Education on 2 November 1997.[http://web.archive.org/web/20041216081315/www.afrique-express.com/archive/CENTRALE/congo/congogvts/congogvt02111997.html "Le gouvernement du Congo formé le 01/11/1997"], ''Afrique Express'' {{fr icon}}. Okombi Salissa's portfolio was expanded on 12 January 1999, when he was appointed as Minister of Technical and Vocational Education, in charge of the Redeployment of the Youth, Civic Instruction, and Sports.[http://www.izf.net/pages/gouvernement/5865/ List of governments of Congo since 1999], izf.net {{fr icon}}. In the [[Republic of the Congo parliamentary election, 2002|2002 parliamentary election]], he was elected to the [[National Assembly of the Republic of the Congo|National Assembly]] as the PCT candidate in Lekana constituency;[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=1093&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Le ministre des Travaux publics, Florent Tsiba, s’incline devant le verdict des urnes"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 1 July 2002 {{fr icon}}. he defeated Minister of Public Works [[Florent Ntsiba]] in the second round of voting, held in June 2002.

-After the 2002 election, Okombi Salissa remained in the government and was moved to the post of Minister of Labour, Employment, and Social Security on 18 August 2002. He was accordingly succeeded by [[Pierre-Michel Nguimbi]] at the Ministry of Technical and Vocational Education on 23 August 2002,[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=1474&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 "André Okombi Salissa remet les clés du ministère de l’Enseignement technique à Pierre-Michel Nguimbi"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 26 August 2002 {{fr icon}}. and he in turn succeeded [[René-Dambert Ndouane]] at the Ministry of Labour on 26 August 2002."Le nouveau ministre du Travail prend officiellement ses fonctions", ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 27 August 2002 {{fr icon}}. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226065232/http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=1492&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 |date=February 26, 2012 }} The newspaper ''Le Choc'' reported on 20 July 2004 that Okombi Salissa, together with three former ministers, had been barred from leaving the country without Sassou Nguesso's approval due to suspicions that they had misused public funds. This report was denied on the next day by public prosecutor Georges Akiéra.[http://www.panapress.com/freenewspor.asp?code=por011816&dte=21/07/2004 "Congo desmente proibição de saída de ministros do país"], Panapress, 21 July 2004 {{pt icon}}.
+After the 2002 election, Okombi Salissa remained in the government and was moved to the post of Minister of Labour, Employment, and Social Security on 18 August 2002. He was accordingly succeeded by [[Pierre-Michel Nguimbi]] at the Ministry of Technical and Vocational Education on 23 August 2002,[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=1474&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 "André Okombi Salissa remet les clés du ministère de l’Enseignement technique à Pierre-Michel Nguimbi"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 26 August 2002 {{fr icon}}. and he in turn succeeded [[René-Dambert Ndouane]] at the Ministry of Labour on 26 August 2002."Le nouveau ministre du Travail prend officiellement ses fonctions", ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 27 August 2002 {{fr icon}}. {{wayback|url=http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=1492&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 |date=20120226065232 |df=yes}} The newspaper ''Le Choc'' reported on 20 July 2004 that Okombi Salissa, together with three former ministers, had been barred from leaving the country without Sassou Nguesso's approval due to suspicions that they had misused public funds. This report was denied on the next day by public prosecutor Georges Akiéra.[http://www.panapress.com/freenewspor.asp?code=por011816&dte=21/07/2004 "Congo desmente proibição de saída de ministros do país"], Panapress, 21 July 2004 {{pt icon}}.

Okombi Salissa was moved from his post as Minister of Labour, Employment, and Social Security to that of Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation on 7 January 2005, and he succeeded [[Isidore Mvouba]] at the head of the Ministry of Transport on 25 January.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=7863&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=20&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Passation de témoin au ministère des Transports"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 25 January 2005 {{fr icon}}. Two years later, on 3 March 2007, he was instead appointed as Minister of Tourism and the Environment; following that appointment, he was succeeded as Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation by [[Emile Ouosso]] on 12 March 2007.Gankama N'Siah, [http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=15113&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=0&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Passation de service au ministère des Transports et de l'aviation civile"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 12 March 2007 {{fr icon}}. As a result of Okombi Salissa's appointment as Minister of Tourism and the Environment, he became President of the [[African Ministerial Conference on the Environment]] (AMCEN) because AMCEN was chaired by Congo-Brazzaville at that time.[http://www.unep.org/pdf/Ourplanet/2007/may/en/OP-2007-05-en-PEOPLE.pdf "Climate Change and the Cryosphere"], ''Our Planet Magazine'', May 2007, page 4.

In the [[Republic of the Congo parliamentary election, 2007|June–August 2007 parliamentary election]], Okombi Salissa was again elected to the National Assembly as the PCT candidate in Lekana; he won the seat in the first round with 91.34% of the vote.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=17017&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=0&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Elections législatives : les 44 élus du premier tour"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 2 July 2007 {{fr icon}}. Following the election, he remained Minister of Tourism and the Environment in the government appointed on 30 December 2007.[http://www.afrik.com/article13266.html "Formation d'un nouveau gouvernement au Congo"], Panapress, 31 December 2007 {{fr icon}}. He was President of AMCEN until its 12th Session in June 2008, when South Africa assumed the presidency instead.[http://www.iisd.ca/africa/vol01/arc0103e.html "Ministerial segment of the Twelfth Session of the African Ministerial Conference on the Environment highlights"], ''AMCEN Bulletin'', volume 1, number 3, 11 June 2008.[http://www.iisd.ca/africa/amcen/amcen12/10june.html "Twelfth Session of the African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN-12)"], iisd.ca.

-As of 2007, Okombi Salissa was the President-Coordinator of the Action Committee for the Defense of Democracy - Youth Movement (CADD-MJ), a political association affiliated with the PCT;[http://www.congopage.com/article.php3?id_article=4336 "André Okombi Salissa, touche l’essentiel : La réinsertion et l’emploi des militants du CADD-MJ (Comité d’Action pour la défense de la Démocratie-Mouvement de Jeunesse)."], Congopage.com, 7 December 2006 {{fr icon}}.Pascal Azad Doko, "André Okombi-Salissa réélu président coordonnateur national du conseil central", ''La Semaine Africaine'', number 2,758, 11 January 2008, page 5 {{fr icon}}. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120052706/http://www.lasemaineafricaine.com/pdf/2758.pdf |date=November 20, 2008 }} he also served as the PCT's Permanent Secretary for Youth, Categorical Unions, and Associated Movements.Roger Ngombé, [http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=15477&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=0&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Le Parti congolais du travail (PCT) se restructure dans le département de la Bouenza"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 4 April 2007 {{fr icon}}. At CADD-MJ's Second Ordinary Congress in December 2007, he was re-elected by acclamation as President-Coordinator of the Central Council of the CADD-MJ.
+As of 2007, Okombi Salissa was the President-Coordinator of the Action Committee for the Defense of Democracy - Youth Movement (CADD-MJ), a political association affiliated with the PCT;[http://www.congopage.com/article.php3?id_article=4336 "André Okombi Salissa, touche l’essentiel : La réinsertion et l’emploi des militants du CADD-MJ (Comité d’Action pour la défense de la Démocratie-Mouvement de Jeunesse)."], Congopage.com, 7 December 2006 {{fr icon}}.Pascal Azad Doko, "André Okombi-Salissa réélu président coordonnateur national du conseil central", ''La Semaine Africaine'', number 2,758, 11 January 2008, page 5 {{fr icon}}. {{wayback|url=http://www.lasemaineafricaine.com/pdf/2758.pdf |date=20081120052706 |df=yes}} he also served as the PCT's Permanent Secretary for Youth, Categorical Unions, and Associated Movements.Roger Ngombé, [http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=15477&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=1&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=0&select_month=0&select_year=0 "Le Parti congolais du travail (PCT) se restructure dans le département de la Bouenza"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 4 April 2007 {{fr icon}}. At CADD-MJ's Second Ordinary Congress in December 2007, he was re-elected by acclamation as President-Coordinator of the Central Council of the CADD-MJ.

The CADD-MJ was critically characterized as a "private militia", and Okombi Salissa described as an [[occult]]ist.[http://www.africa-confidential.com/article-preview/id/3128/No-Title "Curbing their enthusiasm"], ''Africa Confidential'', volume 50, number 12, 12 June 2009. Okombi Salissa owns a number of properties in Brazzaville, including a hotel in the [[Moungali]] district called ''Les Bourgeois''.

-At the time of the [[Republic of the Congo presidential election, 2009|July 2009 presidential election]], Okombi Salissa was Head of the Voter Mobilization Department for Sassou Nguesso's re-election campaign."Élection présidentielle 2009: Direction nationale de campagne du candidat Denis Sassou N'Guesso", ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 9 June 2009 {{fr icon}}. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326015755/http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=30194&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=0&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 |date=March 26, 2012 }} After Sassou Nguesso won re-election, he moved Okombi Salissa to the post of Minister of Technical and Vocational Education, Skills Training, and Employment on 15 September 2009.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/medias/dossiertele/PDF820.pdf "La nouvelle équipe compte trente-sept membres"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', number 820, 16 September 2009, pages 1–2 {{fr icon}}. At the PCT's Sixth Extraordinary Congress, held in July 2011, Okombi Salissa was elected to the PCT's 51-member Political Bureau.Joël Nsoni, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120317080029/http://www.lasemaineafricaine.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1331:denis-sassou-nguesso-aux-congressistes-du-pct-lles-elections-ne-se-gagnent-pas-dans-les-bureaux-elles-se-gagnent-sur-le-terrainr&catid=4:national&Itemid=3 "Denis Sassou Nguesso aux congressistes du P.c.t : «Les élections ne se gagnent pas dans les bureaux. Elles se gagnent sur le terrain»"], ''La Semaine Africaine'', 30 July 2011 {{fr icon}}.
+At the time of the [[Republic of the Congo presidential election, 2009|July 2009 presidential election]], Okombi Salissa was Head of the Voter Mobilization Department for Sassou Nguesso's re-election campaign."Élection présidentielle 2009: Direction nationale de campagne du candidat Denis Sassou N'Guesso", ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 9 June 2009 {{fr icon}}. {{wayback|url=http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/index.php?action=depeche&dep_id=30194&oldaction=liste®pay_id=0&them_id=0&cat_id=0&ss_cat_id=0&LISTE_FROM=40&select_month=0&select_year=0 |date=20120326015755 |df=yes}} After Sassou Nguesso won re-election, he moved Okombi Salissa to the post of Minister of Technical and Vocational Education, Skills Training, and Employment on 15 September 2009.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/medias/dossiertele/PDF820.pdf "La nouvelle équipe compte trente-sept membres"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', number 820, 16 September 2009, pages 1–2 {{fr icon}}. At the PCT's Sixth Extraordinary Congress, held in July 2011, Okombi Salissa was elected to the PCT's 51-member Political Bureau.Joël Nsoni, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120317080029/http://www.lasemaineafricaine.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1331:denis-sassou-nguesso-aux-congressistes-du-pct-lles-elections-ne-se-gagnent-pas-dans-les-bureaux-elles-se-gagnent-sur-le-terrainr&catid=4:national&Itemid=3 "Denis Sassou Nguesso aux congressistes du P.c.t : «Les élections ne se gagnent pas dans les bureaux. Elles se gagnent sur le terrain»"], ''La Semaine Africaine'', 30 July 2011 {{fr icon}}.

In the [[Republic of the Congo parliamentary election, 2012|July–August 2012 parliamentary election]], Okombi Salissa was again elected to the National Assembly as the PCT candidate in Lekana; he won the seat in the first round of voting.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/medias/dossiertele/PDF1539.pdf "Liste des élus au premier tour"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', number 1,539, 23 July 2012, page 8 {{fr icon}}. Following the election, Okombi Salissa was dismissed from the government on 25 September 2012 after 15 years of continuous service;Joël Nsoni, [http://lasemaineafricaine.net/index.php/national/4760-nouveau-gouvernement-six-partants-sept-entrants-et-des-inamovibles "Nouveau gouvernement : Six partants, sept entrants et des inamovibles!"], ''La Semaine Africaine'', 28 September 2012 {{fr icon}}.[http://www.brazzaville-adiac.com/medias/dossiertele/PDF1584.pdf "Une nouvelle équipe de 38 membres publiée hier"], ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', number 1,584, 26 September 2012, page 1 {{fr icon}}. he was succeeded by [[Serge Blaise Zoniaba]] at the Ministry of Technical and Vocational Education on 27 September 2012."Enseignement technique et professionnel : le ministre Serge Blaise Zoniaba s'installe dans ses nouvelles fonctions", ''Les Dépêches de Brazzaville'', 27 September 2012 {{fr icon}}.

-The '''Schit River''' is a right [[tributary]] of the river [[Tazlău River|Tazlău]] in [[Romania]].Ovidiu Gabor - {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305111215/http://www.riob.org/euro-riob/cracovie/27_sep_2004/costrecoverymechanism.pdf |date=March 5, 2009 |title=Economic Mechanism in Water Management }}, map page 10 It discharges into the Tazlău in [[Balcani]].
+The '''Schit River''' is a right [[tributary]] of the river [[Tazlău River|Tazlău]] in [[Romania]].Ovidiu Gabor - {{Wayback |url=http://www.riob.org/euro-riob/cracovie/27_sep_2004/costrecoverymechanism.pdf|title=Economic Mechanism in Water Management|date=20090305111215 |df=yes }}, map page 10 It discharges into the Tazlău in [[Balcani]].

-'''Derrick Clifton Harriott''' (born 6 February 1939) is a [[Jamaica]]n singer and record producer.{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/http:/66.132.135.238/ |date=* |title=Derrick Harriott's website }} – accessed December 2007 He was a member of the '''Jiving Juniors''' before embarking on a solo career. He has produced [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] by [[Big Youth]], Chariot Riders, [[The Chosen Few (reggae group)|The Chosen Few]], [[Dennis Brown]], [[The Ethiopians]], [[Keith & Tex]], [[The Kingstonians]], Rudy Mills, [[Scotty (musician)|Scotty]], [[Sly Dunbar|Sly]] & Revolutionaries, and Winston McAnuff.{{cite web |first=Greg |last=Prato |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p212641/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Derrick Harriott Biography |work=Allmusic.com |accessdate=18 November 2009}}
+'''Derrick Clifton Harriott''' (born 6 February 1939) is a [[Jamaica]]n singer and record producer.{{Wayback |df=yes|date=* |url=http:/66.132.135.238/ |title=Derrick Harriott's website}} – accessed December 2007 He was a member of the '''Jiving Juniors''' before embarking on a solo career. He has produced [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] by [[Big Youth]], Chariot Riders, [[The Chosen Few (reggae group)|The Chosen Few]], [[Dennis Brown]], [[The Ethiopians]], [[Keith & Tex]], [[The Kingstonians]], Rudy Mills, [[Scotty (musician)|Scotty]], [[Sly Dunbar|Sly]] & Revolutionaries, and Winston McAnuff.{{cite web |first=Greg |last=Prato |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p212641/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Derrick Harriott Biography |work=Allmusic.com |accessdate=18 November 2009}}

2016-11-14 05:04:41 749411312 Fluxbot GreenC bot Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/GreenC bot|GreenC bot]] ([[User talk:GreenC bot|talk]]) to last version by Ser Amantio di Nicolao --- \n

@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@\n
| notable_instruments = [[Fender Precision Bass]], [[Fender Jazz Bass]]
}}

-'''Phillip James''' "'''Phil'''" '''Small''' (born 2 August 1954) is an Australian musician and songwriter, who is the bass guitarist for the [[Pub rock (Australia)|pub rock]] band [[Cold Chisel]].McFarlane {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040419101605/www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=213 |date=April 19, 2004 |title='Cold Chisel' entry }}. Retrieved 17 February 2010.Spencer et al, (2007) [http://www.whiteroom.com.au/howlspace/whoswho/PHPMuso.php?categorywho=musos&userasks=52285 Small, Phil] entry. Retrieved 17 February 2010. He has written songs for Cold Chisel including the hit single, "[[My Baby (Cold Chisel song)|My Baby]]" (sung by the band's guitarist [[Ian Moss]] rather than usual lead singer [[Jimmy Barnes]]), for the 1980 album ''[[East (album)|East]]'', "Notion for You" off the ''[[Teenage Love (album)|Teenage Love]]'' album and "The Game" (from ''[[Twentieth Century (Cold Chisel album)|Twentieth Century]]''). For Cold Chisel's 1998 comeback album, ''[[The Last Wave of Summer]]'', Small contributed the unnamed fifteenth track, "Once Around the Sun", as well as co-writing with [[Steve Prestwich]] and [[Don Walker (musician)|Don Walker]], "A Better Time a Better Place", as a B side to one of the singles.
+'''Phillip James''' "'''Phil'''" '''Small''' (born 2 August 1954) is an Australian musician and songwriter, who is the bass guitarist for the [[Pub rock (Australia)|pub rock]] band [[Cold Chisel]].McFarlane {{Wayback |df=yes|date=20040419101605 |url=www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=213 |title='Cold Chisel' entry}}. Retrieved 17 February 2010.Spencer et al, (2007) [http://www.whiteroom.com.au/howlspace/whoswho/PHPMuso.php?categorywho=musos&userasks=52285 Small, Phil] entry. Retrieved 17 February 2010. He has written songs for Cold Chisel including the hit single, "[[My Baby (Cold Chisel song)|My Baby]]" (sung by the band's guitarist [[Ian Moss]] rather than usual lead singer [[Jimmy Barnes]]), for the 1980 album ''[[East (album)|East]]'', "Notion for You" off the ''[[Teenage Love (album)|Teenage Love]]'' album and "The Game" (from ''[[Twentieth Century (Cold Chisel album)|Twentieth Century]]''). For Cold Chisel's 1998 comeback album, ''[[The Last Wave of Summer]]'', Small contributed the unnamed fifteenth track, "Once Around the Sun", as well as co-writing with [[Steve Prestwich]] and [[Don Walker (musician)|Don Walker]], "A Better Time a Better Place", as a B side to one of the singles.

Small has played in a number of other bands such as Planet (1971), Palladium (1972), Pound (1985), The Earls of Duke (1985–1988), Hot Ice (1986), The Outsiders (1989) and [[Billy Thorpe|Billy Thorpe Band]] (2005). He also played with fellow Cold Chisel members, [[Jimmy Barnes]] in his band for the 1999 tour; and Ian Moss in late 2000 through the eastern states of Australia.

There are also advent counters that use candles, stories or toys of every day in December until Christmas Day, but are not in traditional calendar form.

2016-11-14 05:22:48 749413515 Fluxbot GreenC bot Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/GreenC bot|GreenC bot]] ([[User talk:GreenC bot|talk]]) to last version by Clisamurai --- \n

@@ -48,7 +48,7 @@\n

==India==
[[File:Doon School Old Boys' Society.jpg|thumb|200px|Logo of [[The Doon School Old Boys' Society]].]]
-[[The Doon School]] maintains its own old boys' society ([http://www.dsobs.net/ The Doon School Old Boys' Society]) for social connections and fundraising on behalf of the School.[http://www.doonschool.com/info/ouroldboys.htm The Doon School: Our Old Boys] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308085008/http://www.doonschool.com/info/ouroldboys.htm |date=March 8, 2009 }} Graduates of The Doon School are known as ''Doscos'', or simply, as Old Boys.
+[[The Doon School]] maintains its own old boys' society ([http://www.dsobs.net/ The Doon School Old Boys' Society]) for social connections and fundraising on behalf of the School.[http://www.doonschool.com/info/ouroldboys.htm The Doon School: Our Old Boys] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.doonschool.com/info/ouroldboys.htm |date=20090308085008 }} Graduates of The Doon School are known as ''Doscos'', or simply, as Old Boys.

Former students of the [[Welham Boys School]] refer to their society as the Welham Old Boys Society. Though the school was founded in 1937, the society was not founded until 1983. The group is intended to encourage Welham graduates to aid in the school's success through their union; they have established scholarships and [[Bursary|bursaries]] for deserving students. The Welham Old Boys Network has established definite membership criteria, as well as requiring a subscription fee.{{cite web|url=http://www.welhamoldboys.com/society.asp |title=Welham Old Boys Society |publisher=Welhamoldboys.com |date= |accessdate=24 June 2012}}
2016-11-14 04:55:32 749410169 Fluxbot GreenC bot Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/GreenC bot|GreenC bot]] ([[User talk:GreenC bot|talk]]) to last version by Dl2000 --- \n
+++ \n
@@ -6,14 +6,14 @@\n
Born in London in 1833, the son of Thomas Archdeacon Lewis (1780-1862), a secretary to [[Charles Blomfield]], [[Bishop of London]]. Although trained as an [[architect]], Lewis founded a firm of organ builders with John Tunstall and John Whitacker in about 1860. In 1866, the firm moved into premises in Shepherds Lane (now Ferndale Road), [[Brixton]]. Under Lewis's direction, the firm built instruments ranging from small chamber organs to major [[cathedral]] and concert organs. Lewis was strongly inspired by the organs built in Germany by [[Edmund Schulze]] and in France by [[Aristide Cavaillé-Coll]]. He was renowned for instruments that had a bright, vibrant [[Timbre|tone]].{{cite web|url=http://www.organrecitals.com/southwark.php |title=Southwark Cathedral |publisher=Organrecitals.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-19}} Lewis left the firm before 1900, but it continued to maintain the standards set by its founder. In 1919, there was a merger with [[Henry Willis & Sons]] who moved into the Brixton works and traded as '''Henry Willis and Son and Lewis and Company Ltd''' until 1925 when the Lewis name was dropped. T. C. Lewis continued to build organs for some time after leaving the firm that he had founded.The Organ: An Encyclopedia, Douglas E Bush & Richard Kassel, Routledge 2006 page 302

==Notable Lewis organs==
-* [[Old St. Paul's, Wellington]], New Zealand, 1877[http://cathedral.wellington.net.nz/index.php/Cathedral_Organ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019014200/http://cathedral.wellington.net.nz/index.php/Cathedral_Organ |date=October 19, 2009 }}
+* [[Old St. Paul's, Wellington]], New Zealand, 1877[http://cathedral.wellington.net.nz/index.php/Cathedral_Organ] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://cathedral.wellington.net.nz/index.php/Cathedral_Organ |date=20091019014200 }}
* [[Ripon Cathedral]], 1878[http://www.riponcathedral.org.uk/organ01.php ]{{dead link|date=November 2013}}
* [[Newcastle Cathedral]], 1880
* [[St John the Evangelist, Upper Norwood]], London 1882{{cite web|title=The Lewis Organ|url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/offroadrunner/the_organ.htm|publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk|accessdate=19 November 2013}}
* [[St Paul's Cathedral, Melbourne]], Australia 1891{{cite web|url=http://www.ohta.org.au/organs/organs/StPaulsMelb.html |title=St Paul's Cathedral, Melbourne |publisher=Ohta.org.au |date= |accessdate=2013-11-19}}
* [[Southwark Cathedral]], London 1897{{cite web|url=http://cathedral.southwark.anglican.org/worship/music-and-choirs |title=Music and Choirs - Worship - Southwark Cathedral |publisher=Cathedral.southwark.anglican.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-19}}
* [[Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum]], Glasgow 1901{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgowmuseums.com/assets/fileStore/TheKelvingroveOrgan.pdf |title=Glasgow Museums |publisher=Glasgow Museums |date=2009-11-17 |accessdate=2013-11-19}}
-* [[Church House (Presbyterian Church in Ireland)]], Belfast 1906[http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/wk/organs/assembly.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090728070207/http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/wk/organs/assembly.html |date=July 28, 2009 }}
+* [[Church House (Presbyterian Church in Ireland)]], Belfast 1906[http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/wk/organs/assembly.html ] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/wk/organs/assembly.html |date=20090728070207 }}
* [[Westminster Cathedral]], London, "Apse organ" 1910{{cite web|url=http://www.organrecitals.com/westcath.php |title=Westminster Cathedral |publisher=Organrecitals.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-19}}
* [[All Saints Church, Maidstone]], "Main Organ"{{cite web|url=http://www.maidstoneallsaints.freeserve.co.uk/organ.htm |title=Organ |publisher=Maidstoneallsaints.freeserve.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-19}}
* [[St. George's, Cullercoats]]
2009-03-05 21:56:43 275259119 ClueBot Polbot Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contributions/69.254.195.131|69.254.195.131]] to version by J.delanoy. False positive? [[User:ClueBot/FalsePositives|Report it]]. Thanks, [[User:ClueBot|ClueBot]]. (624151) (Bot) --- \n
+++ \n
@@ -1,27 +1,39 @@\n
-{{Cleanup FJC Bio}}
-'''William Clark''' (February 1, 1891 – October 10, 1957) was a [[United States federal judge]].
+'''William Clark''' ([[February 1]], [[1891]] – [[October 10]], [[1957]]) was a [[United States federal judge]].

-Clark was born in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. He received a [[B.A.]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1911. He received a [[M.A.]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1912. He received a [[LL.B.]] from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1915. He was in the [[United States Army]] from 1917 to 1918. He was in private practice of law in [[Newark, New Jersey]] from 1920 to 1923. He was a judge to the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals from 1923 to 1924. He was in the [[United States Army]] from 1942 to 1945. He was a Chief justice, Allied Appeals Court in Nuremberg, Germany from 1949 to 1954.
+Clark was born on [[February 1]], [[1891]] in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. His father, John William Clark, was president of the Clark Thread Company of Newark.Schleicher, William A. and Susan Winter. [http://books.google.com/books?id=pl6JF54vnRIC ''In the Somerset Hills: The Landed Gentry'']. Arcadia, 1997. (Clark Thread Co. later merged with [[Coats PLC|J. & P. Coats]] to become Coats & Clark Inc.) His mother, Margaretta Cameron Clark, was the daughter of [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] [[J. Donald Cameron]].[http://www.historicalsocietyofsomersethills.org/blairsden.php The History of Blairsden in Peapack, NJ], Historical Society of The Somerset Hills. He earned successive degrees at [[Harvard University]], starting with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] at the age of 20 in 1911, followed by an [[Master of Arts (postgraduate)|M.A.]] a year later, and finally an [[Bachelor of Law|LL.B.]] from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1915. Two years later, when the United States declared war, he joined the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]], where he stayed until 1918.

-Clark was a federal judge to the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]]. Clark received a [[recess appointment]] from Calvin Coolidge on May 21, 1925, to a seat vacated by [[Charles F. Lynch]]. nominated on December 8, 1925; He was confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] on December 17, 1925, and received commission the same day. Clark's service was terminated on June 25, 1938, due to appointment to another judicial position.
+Clark married Marjory Blair, daughter of investment banker [[C. Ledyard Blair]], on [[September 20]], [[1913]]. Eight hundred guests were invited to the celebration at the [[Blairsden Mansion]] in [[Peapack-Gladstone, New Jersey]], not far from the Clark family's own estate, Peachcroft. Their daughter Anne was born on [[July 18]], [[1914]]. [[Anne Clark Martindell]] would go on to serve in the [[New Jersey Senate]] and as [[United States Ambassador to New Zealand]]. Their son [[Blair Clark|Ledyard Blair Clark]] was born on [[August 22]], [[1917]] and would become a prominent journalist and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] activist.

-Clark was a federal judge to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]]. Clark was nominated by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] on June 10, 1938, to a seat vacated by [[Joseph Whitaker Thompson]]. He was confirmed by the United States Senate on June 16, 1938, and received commission on June 25, 1938. Clark's service was terminated on March 24, 1943, due to resignation.
+In 1920, Clark started out the practice of law in Newark, which lasted a bare four years before he became a judge of the [[New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals]] in 1923. He was only a state judge for one year. On [[May 21]], [[1925]], he received a [[recess appointment]] from President [[Calvin Coolidge]] to the [[U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey]]. His appointment was confirmed by the [[United States Senate|Senate]] later that year.
+
+On [[June 10]], [[1938]], President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] nominated Clark for elevation to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]]. He was confirmed on [[June 16]] and joined the court on [[June 25]].
+
+On [[March 24]], [[1943]], Clark resigned his judgeship and became a full-time member of the [[United States Army]], this time as part of [[World War II]]. This lasted until the war's conclusion in 1945.
+
+After Clark's first marriage ended in divorce, he married Sonia Tomara, a foreign correspondent for the ''[[New York Herald Tribune]]'', on [[October 4]], [[1947]] in [[Paris]].[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F7071EFE3B5E17738DDDA80894D9415B8788F1D3 "Ex-Judge Clark Weds Miss Tomara in Paris"]. ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[November 1]], [[1947]]. Accessed [[June 13]], [[2008]].
+
+In 1949, Clark became the chief justice of the [[Allied High Commission]] Court of Appeals in [[Nuremberg]], [[Germany]]. He stayed in this position until 1954. He died three years later, on [[October 10]], [[1957]].
+
+==References==
+{{Reflist}}

-The '''Supan River''' or '''Sopan River''' is a right [[tributary]] of the [[Trotuş River]] in [[Romania]].Ovidiu Gabor - {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305111215/http://www.riob.org/euro-riob/cracovie/27_sep_2004/costrecoverymechanism.pdf |date=March 5, 2009 |title=Economic Mechanism in Water Management }}, map page 10

2016-11-14 05:16:35 749412787 Fluxbot GreenC bot Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/GreenC bot|GreenC bot]] ([[User talk:GreenC bot|talk]]) to last version by Narky Blert --- \n

@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@\n
{{about|the [[Flag of Northern Ireland]]|the traditional provincial flag of Ulster|Flag of Ulster}}

[[File:Ulster banner.svg|thumb|right|The Ulster Banner (Edwardian Crown version following [[coronation of Queen Elizabeth II]] in 1953)]]
-The '''Ulster Banner'''{{cite book |last=Groom|first=Nick|title=The Union Jack: the Story of the British Flag |publisher=Atlantic Books|year=2006|isbn=978-1-84354-336-7 |page=295}} is a [[heraldry|heraldic]] [[Banner#Heraldic banners|banner]] taken from the former [[coat of arms of Northern Ireland]], consisting of a red cross on a white field, upon which is a crowned six-pointed star with a [[Red Hand of Ulster|red hand]] in the centre. It was the flag of the former [[Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland|Government of Northern Ireland]] and common [[flag of Northern Ireland]] from 1953 until that government [[Northern Ireland Constitution Act 1973|was abolished]] in 1972. It was adopted to mark the [[coronation of Queen Elizabeth II]], and was first flown over [[Parliament Buildings (Northern Ireland)|Parliament Buildings]] on 1 July 1953, in honour of the Queen's visit. The [[Minister of Home Affairs (Northern Ireland)|Minister of Home Affairs]] announced that, while the [[Union Jack]] was the only standard officially recognised, those who wished to have a distinctive Ulster symbol might use the banner.McCartney, Clem & Bryson, Lucy. ''Clashing Symbols? A report on the use of flags, anthems and other national symbols in Northern Ireland.'' The Institute for Irish Studies, Queen's University of Belfast, 1994, p 42 ISBN 085 389 538 4 Since 1972, the Ulster Banner has had no official status and is not used by the current [[Northern Ireland Executive|Northern Ireland government]] or by the British government.{{cite web |url=http://www.flaginstitute.org/wp/flags/ulster/ |title=Ulster |website=[[Flag Institute]] |quote=The Ulster flag is different from the Ulster Banner, which was the former flag of Northern Ireland but now holds no official status.}}{{cite book |last=Minahan |first=James |year=2009 |title=The Complete Guide to National Symbols and Emblems |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=0313344973 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=486 |quote=The official flag of the province is the Union Jack. There is no official national flag of Northern Ireland, following the Northern Ireland Constitution Act of 1973, nor any unofficial flag universally accepted in Northern Ireland.}}{{cite book |last=McCormick |first=John |year=2012 |title=Contemporary Britain |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=113701718X |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |page=53 |quote=The old flag of Northern Ireland – a red hand inside a white star on a red cross – has strong connections with the Protestant community, and is no longer official but is still occasionally flown. The official flag of Northern Ireland is the Union Flag.}}{{cite book |authors=Paul Nolan and Dominic Bryan |year=2016 |title=Flags: Towards a New Understanding |url=https://www.qub.ac.uk/schools/IrishStudiesGateway/FileStore/Filetoupload,566329,en.pdf |publisher=Queen's University Belfast |page=6 |quote=following the Northern Ireland Constitution Act of 1973, the Ulster Banner ceased to have any official standing, but there followed a huge increase in its unofficial use as a symbol of loyalism.}}[http://www.sportni.net/NR/rdonlyres/0F8CE8FF-9D19-4C11-9DF9-0B69E033C732/0/Promotingfairplayinsport.pdf Promoting Fair Play in Sport]. [[Sport Northern Ireland]]. p. 9. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407042030/http://www.sportni.net/NR/rdonlyres/0F8CE8FF-9D19-4C11-9DF9-0B69E033C732/0/Promotingfairplayinsport.pdf |date=April 7, 2013 }} "Many existing flags have no official status and this includes the former Northern Ireland 'flag' (or flag of the Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland or Ulster Banner) that only had official status during the life of the NI Government between 1953 and 1972, and would be regarded by many as contentious in the current political circumstance".{{cite web |url=https://northernireland.foundation/sharedfuture/research/flags/ |title=Flags |date= |website=Northern Ireland Foundation |quote= It was the official flag of Northern Ireland from then until the Northern Ireland government was suspended in 1972, and has had no official standing since that time.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/northern-ireland-news/new-northern-ireland-flag-should-be-created-says-lord-kilclooney-1-5753950 |title=New Northern Ireland flag should be created, says Lord Kilclooney |date=17 December 2013 |website=[[The News Letter]] |quote=[[John Taylor, Baron Kilclooney|Lord Kilclooney]], the former Ulster Unionist deputy leader, is a vice chairman of Westminsters all-party group on flags and heraldry which promotes the flying of the Union Flag. He told the News Letter [...] 'whilst England (St George's Cross) Scotland (St Andrew's Cross) and Wales (The Dragon) have individual regional flags, the Flags Institute in London confirms that Northern Ireland has no official regional flag. It should now be possible to design a regional flag [...] which is acceptable to both communities in Northern Ireland'.}}{{cite web |url=http://archive.niassembly.gov.uk/record/reports/000606.htm |title=Union Flag (Executive Buildings) |date=6 June 2000 |website=[[Northern Ireland Assembly]] |quote=Mr [[Fraser Agnew]]: The Ulster flag] [...] was a civil flag for Northern Ireland, but its official status was abolished when the Northern Ireland Parliament was closed down in 1973. Thereafter, the Union flag was made the official flag in Northern Ireland. That is a fact.}}{{cite web |url=https://flagspot.net/flags/gb-ni.html |title=Northern Ireland (United Kingdom) |date= |website=[[Flags of the World]] |quote=}} However, the Ulster Banner is still in common use by loyalists/[[Unionism in Ireland|unionists]], and to represent Northern Ireland internationally in some sporting competitions. It has become a symbol of [[Ulster loyalism]]{{cite web |url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/symbols/flags.htm |title=Flags used in Northern Ireland |date= |website=[[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN) |quote=this particular flag of Northern Ireland is seen as staunchly Loyalist}} and is [[Northern Ireland flags issue|a contentious symbol]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23952654 |title=Bangor man travels the world with Northern Ireland flag |date=9 September 2013 |website=BBC News |quote=The red cross on a white background flutters from many a lamppost in Northern Ireland, and is often a divisive symbol between unionists and nationalists.}} In recent years there have been calls for a new, neutral flag for Northern Ireland to replace the Ulster Banner.{{cite web |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/find-a-neutral-flag-for-all-of-northern-ireland-richard-haass-issues-challenge-to-parties-29803598.html |title=Find a neutral flag for all of Northern Ireland: Richard Haass issues challenge to parties |date=3 December 2013 |website=[[Belfast Telegraph]]}}
+The '''Ulster Banner'''{{cite book |last=Groom|first=Nick|title=The Union Jack: the Story of the British Flag |publisher=Atlantic Books|year=2006|isbn=978-1-84354-336-7 |page=295}} is a [[heraldry|heraldic]] [[Banner#Heraldic banners|banner]] taken from the former [[coat of arms of Northern Ireland]], consisting of a red cross on a white field, upon which is a crowned six-pointed star with a [[Red Hand of Ulster|red hand]] in the centre. It was the flag of the former [[Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland|Government of Northern Ireland]] and common [[flag of Northern Ireland]] from 1953 until that government [[Northern Ireland Constitution Act 1973|was abolished]] in 1972. It was adopted to mark the [[coronation of Queen Elizabeth II]], and was first flown over [[Parliament Buildings (Northern Ireland)|Parliament Buildings]] on 1 July 1953, in honour of the Queen's visit. The [[Minister of Home Affairs (Northern Ireland)|Minister of Home Affairs]] announced that, while the [[Union Jack]] was the only standard officially recognised, those who wished to have a distinctive Ulster symbol might use the banner.McCartney, Clem & Bryson, Lucy. ''Clashing Symbols? A report on the use of flags, anthems and other national symbols in Northern Ireland.'' The Institute for Irish Studies, Queen's University of Belfast, 1994, p 42 ISBN 085 389 538 4 Since 1972, the Ulster Banner has had no official status and is not used by the current [[Northern Ireland Executive|Northern Ireland government]] or by the British government.{{cite web |url=http://www.flaginstitute.org/wp/flags/ulster/ |title=Ulster |website=[[Flag Institute]] |quote=The Ulster flag is different from the Ulster Banner, which was the former flag of Northern Ireland but now holds no official status.}}{{cite book |last=Minahan |first=James |year=2009 |title=The Complete Guide to National Symbols and Emblems |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=0313344973 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |page=486 |quote=The official flag of the province is the Union Jack. There is no official national flag of Northern Ireland, following the Northern Ireland Constitution Act of 1973, nor any unofficial flag universally accepted in Northern Ireland.}}{{cite book |last=McCormick |first=John |year=2012 |title=Contemporary Britain |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=113701718X |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |page=53 |quote=The old flag of Northern Ireland – a red hand inside a white star on a red cross – has strong connections with the Protestant community, and is no longer official but is still occasionally flown. The official flag of Northern Ireland is the Union Flag.}}{{cite book |authors=Paul Nolan and Dominic Bryan |year=2016 |title=Flags: Towards a New Understanding |url=https://www.qub.ac.uk/schools/IrishStudiesGateway/FileStore/Filetoupload,566329,en.pdf |publisher=Queen's University Belfast |page=6 |quote=following the Northern Ireland Constitution Act of 1973, the Ulster Banner ceased to have any official standing, but there followed a huge increase in its unofficial use as a symbol of loyalism.}}[http://www.sportni.net/NR/rdonlyres/0F8CE8FF-9D19-4C11-9DF9-0B69E033C732/0/Promotingfairplayinsport.pdf Promoting Fair Play in Sport]. [[Sport Northern Ireland]]. p. 9. {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.sportni.net/NR/rdonlyres/0F8CE8FF-9D19-4C11-9DF9-0B69E033C732/0/Promotingfairplayinsport.pdf|date=20130407042030}} "Many existing flags have no official status and this includes the former Northern Ireland 'flag' (or flag of the Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland or Ulster Banner) that only had official status during the life of the NI Government between 1953 and 1972, and would be regarded by many as contentious in the current political circumstance".{{cite web |url=https://northernireland.foundation/sharedfuture/research/flags/ |title=Flags |date= |website=Northern Ireland Foundation |quote= It was the official flag of Northern Ireland from then until the Northern Ireland government was suspended in 1972, and has had no official standing since that time.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/northern-ireland-news/new-northern-ireland-flag-should-be-created-says-lord-kilclooney-1-5753950 |title=New Northern Ireland flag should be created, says Lord Kilclooney |date=17 December 2013 |website=[[The News Letter]] |quote=[[John Taylor, Baron Kilclooney|Lord Kilclooney]], the former Ulster Unionist deputy leader, is a vice chairman of Westminsters all-party group on flags and heraldry which promotes the flying of the Union Flag. He told the News Letter [...] 'whilst England (St George's Cross) Scotland (St Andrew's Cross) and Wales (The Dragon) have individual regional flags, the Flags Institute in London confirms that Northern Ireland has no official regional flag. It should now be possible to design a regional flag [...] which is acceptable to both communities in Northern Ireland'.}}{{cite web |url=http://archive.niassembly.gov.uk/record/reports/000606.htm |title=Union Flag (Executive Buildings) |date=6 June 2000 |website=[[Northern Ireland Assembly]] |quote=Mr [[Fraser Agnew]]: The Ulster flag] [...] was a civil flag for Northern Ireland, but its official status was abolished when the Northern Ireland Parliament was closed down in 1973. Thereafter, the Union flag was made the official flag in Northern Ireland. That is a fact.}}{{cite web |url=https://flagspot.net/flags/gb-ni.html |title=Northern Ireland (United Kingdom) |date= |website=[[Flags of the World]] |quote=}} However, the Ulster Banner is still in common use by loyalists/[[Unionism in Ireland|unionists]], and to represent Northern Ireland internationally in some sporting competitions. It has become a symbol of [[Ulster loyalism]]{{cite web |url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/symbols/flags.htm |title=Flags used in Northern Ireland |date= |website=[[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN) |quote=this particular flag of Northern Ireland is seen as staunchly Loyalist}} and is [[Northern Ireland flags issue|a contentious symbol]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23952654 |title=Bangor man travels the world with Northern Ireland flag |date=9 September 2013 |website=BBC News |quote=The red cross on a white background flutters from many a lamppost in Northern Ireland, and is often a divisive symbol between unionists and nationalists.}} In recent years there have been calls for a new, neutral flag for Northern Ireland to replace the Ulster Banner.{{cite web |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/find-a-neutral-flag-for-all-of-northern-ireland-richard-haass-issues-challenge-to-parties-29803598.html |title=Find a neutral flag for all of Northern Ireland: Richard Haass issues challenge to parties |date=3 December 2013 |website=[[Belfast Telegraph]]}}

==Origin==
[[File:Coat of Arms of Northern Ireland.svg|thumb|left|[[Coat of Arms of Northern Ireland|Arms]] of the [[Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland|former government of Northern Ireland]], 1924–1972]]
@@ -20,11 +20,11 @@\n
In 1924, the [[Government of Northern Ireland]] was granted [[Coat of arms of Northern Ireland|its own coat of arms]] by [[Royal warrant (document)|Royal Warrant]] and had the right to display these arms on a [[Heraldic flag|flag or banner]]. This right was exercised for the [[Coronation of the British monarch|Coronation]] of [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] in 1953. From 1953 until 1972, the flag was used officially by the Government of Northern Ireland and also as a ''de facto'' civic [[Flag of Northern Ireland|flag for Northern Ireland]]. In 1972, the Government and [[Parliament of Northern Ireland|Parliament]] of Northern Ireland were abolished by the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] under the [[Northern Ireland Constitution Act 1973]].

===Later use===
-Since the Government of Northern Ireland was abolished in 1972, the flag (and variations thereof) has continued to be used by [[Unionism in Ireland|unionists]]. In 2004, [[Belfast City Council]] commissioned a study on the flying of flags which noted that the Ulster Banner continued to be flown, alongside the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|Union flag]], by three unionist-controlled [[local government in Northern Ireland|local authorities]] in Northern Ireland: [[Ards (borough)|Ards Borough Council]], [[Carrickfergus Borough Council]] and [[Castlereagh (borough)|Castlereagh Borough Council]].http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/equality/docs/FlyingOfUnionFlagEQIA.pdf {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326225420/http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/equality/docs/FlyingOfUnionFlagEQIA.pdf |date=March 26, 2009 }}
+Since the Government of Northern Ireland was abolished in 1972, the flag (and variations thereof) has continued to be used by [[Unionism in Ireland|unionists]]. In 2004, [[Belfast City Council]] commissioned a study on the flying of flags which noted that the Ulster Banner continued to be flown, alongside the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|Union flag]], by three unionist-controlled [[local government in Northern Ireland|local authorities]] in Northern Ireland: [[Ards (borough)|Ards Borough Council]], [[Carrickfergus Borough Council]] and [[Castlereagh (borough)|Castlereagh Borough Council]].http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/equality/docs/FlyingOfUnionFlagEQIA.pdf {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/equality/docs/FlyingOfUnionFlagEQIA.pdf |date=20090326225420 }}

==International sport==

-The Ulster Banner is used to represent Northern Ireland at the [[Commonwealth Games]][http://www.thecgf.com/countries/links.asp Commonwealth Games Federation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713081615/http://www.thecgf.com/countries/links.asp |date=July 13, 2007 }}[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/graphics/gallery/commonwealth06/opening/nireut.jpg ''Telegraph''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406182956/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/graphics/gallery/commonwealth06/opening/nireut.jpg |date=April 6, 2008 }} and by [[FIFA]] to represent the [[Northern Ireland national football team]].[http://www.fifa.com/associations/association=nir/countryInfo.html Northern Ireland: Country information], FIFA.com
+The Ulster Banner is used to represent Northern Ireland at the [[Commonwealth Games]][http://www.thecgf.com/countries/links.asp Commonwealth Games Federation] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.thecgf.com/countries/links.asp |date=20070713081615 }}[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/graphics/gallery/commonwealth06/opening/nireut.jpg ''Telegraph''] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/graphics/gallery/commonwealth06/opening/nireut.jpg |date=20080406182956 }} and by [[FIFA]] to represent the [[Northern Ireland national football team]].[http://www.fifa.com/associations/association=nir/countryInfo.html Northern Ireland: Country information], FIFA.com

| website = {{URL|www.ricolove.com}}

-'''Richard Preston Butler, Jr.''' (born December 3, 1982), better known by his stage name '''Rico Love''', is an American singer-songwriter, record producer and rapper. He was born in [[New Orleans|New Orleans, Louisiana]], but split his childhood between [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] and New York City's Harlem neighborhood. He attended [[Florida A&M University|Florida A&M]] and, while visiting [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], worked his way into the music industry through connections with [[Usher (singer)|Usher]], who would become Love's mentor. The first song Love ever wrote in his career was "Throwback" for which ended up on Usher's 2004 album "[[Confessions (Usher album)|''Confessions'']]." Love success continued writing and producing hit records such as Usher's "[[There Goes My Baby (Usher song)|There Goes My Baby]]" and "[[Hey Daddy (Daddy's Home)]]", [[Nelly]]'s "[[Just a Dream (Nelly song)|Just a Dream]]" and "[[Gone (Nelly song)|Gone]]", as well as [[Beyoncé Knowles]]' "[[Sweet Dreams (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Sweet Dreams]]".http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songNum=705878http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songNum=702982{{cite web|url=http://www.sesac.com/News/Article.aspx/2010/Summer/Rico%20Love |title=Rico Love |publisher=SESAC |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} and has contributed to works which have gone on to win [[Grammy Award|Grammys]] such as Beyoncé's 2009 Best Contemporary R&B album ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'',https://web.archive.org/web/20120503164723/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=beyonce&title=&year=All&genre=All Usher's 2010 Best Contemporary R&B album ''[[Raymond v. Raymond]]'', and Usher's 2010 Best Male R&B Vocal Performance "[[There Goes My Baby (Usher song)|There Goes My Baby]]". In addition Love has written and produced records for [[Kelly Rowland]],{{cite web|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/celebrity-2/2011/03/09/nelly-and-kelly-reunite/46788 |title=Nelly and Kelly reunite |work=Star Observer |date=March 9, 2011 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Diddy – Dirty Money]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/04/28/rico-love-says-diddy-dirty-money-album-will-be-worth-the-wait/ |title=Rico Love Says Diddy-Dirty Money Album Will Be Worth the Wait |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]],{{cite web|url=http://neonlimelight.com/2010/07/09/exclusive-songwriter-rico-love-talks-chris-browns-amazing-songwriting-progress/ |title=Exclusive: Songwriter Rico Love Talks Chris Brown’s "Amazing" Songwriting Progress |publisher=Neonlimelight.com |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Alexandra Burke]], [[Keri Hilson]],{{cite web|url=http://theurbandaily.com/music/shamika-sanders/beyonces-songwriter-rico-love-the-music-business-is-like-high-school/ |title=Rico Love: The Music Industry Is Like High School |publisher=The Urban Daily |date=June 8, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]],{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fergie-has-sex-and-the-citys-theme-labels-or-love-57108997.html |title=Fergie Has Sex and the City's Theme, 'Labels Or Love' |date=May 5, 2008 |location=California |publisher=Prnewswire.com |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} and [[Fantasia Barrino|Fantasia]].http://thatgrapejuice.net/2010/05/rico-love-talks-fantasias-album-wanted-show-people-seductive-side/
+'''Richard Preston Butler, Jr.''' (born December 3, 1982), better known by his stage name '''Rico Love''', is an American singer-songwriter, record producer and rapper. He was born in [[New Orleans|New Orleans, Louisiana]], but split his childhood between [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] and New York City's Harlem neighborhood. He attended [[Florida A&M University|Florida A&M]] and, while visiting [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], worked his way into the music industry through connections with [[Usher (singer)|Usher]], who would become Love's mentor. The first song Love ever wrote in his career was "Throwback" for which ended up on Usher's 2004 album "[[Confessions (Usher album)|''Confessions'']]." Love success continued writing and producing hit records such as Usher's "[[There Goes My Baby (Usher song)|There Goes My Baby]]" and "[[Hey Daddy (Daddy's Home)]]", [[Nelly]]'s "[[Just a Dream (Nelly song)|Just a Dream]]" and "[[Gone (Nelly song)|Gone]]", as well as [[Beyoncé Knowles]]' "[[Sweet Dreams (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Sweet Dreams]]".http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songNum=705878http://www.sesac.com/Repertory/SongSearch.aspx?songNum=702982{{cite web|url=http://www.sesac.com/News/Article.aspx/2010/Summer/Rico%20Love |title=Rico Love |publisher=SESAC |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} and has contributed to works which have gone on to win [[Grammy Award|Grammys]] such as Beyoncé's 2009 Best Contemporary R&B album ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'',https://web.archive.org/web/20120503164723/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=beyonce&title=&year=All&genre=All Usher's 2010 Best Contemporary R&B album ''[[Raymond v. Raymond]]'',[https://web.archive.org/web/20120503164723/http://www.grammy.com/nominees Nominees And Winners | GRAMMY.com] {{WebCite|url=http://www.webcitation.org/5n9wlZGhw|date =January 29, 2010}} and Usher's 2010 Best Male R&B Vocal Performance "[[There Goes My Baby (Usher song)|There Goes My Baby]]". In addition Love has written and produced records for [[Kelly Rowland]],{{cite web|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/celebrity-2/2011/03/09/nelly-and-kelly-reunite/46788 |title=Nelly and Kelly reunite |work=Star Observer |date=March 9, 2011 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Diddy – Dirty Money]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/04/28/rico-love-says-diddy-dirty-money-album-will-be-worth-the-wait/ |title=Rico Love Says Diddy-Dirty Money Album Will Be Worth the Wait |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]],{{cite web|url=http://neonlimelight.com/2010/07/09/exclusive-songwriter-rico-love-talks-chris-browns-amazing-songwriting-progress/ |title=Exclusive: Songwriter Rico Love Talks Chris Brown’s "Amazing" Songwriting Progress |publisher=Neonlimelight.com |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Alexandra Burke]], [[Keri Hilson]],{{cite web|url=http://theurbandaily.com/music/shamika-sanders/beyonces-songwriter-rico-love-the-music-business-is-like-high-school/ |title=Rico Love: The Music Industry Is Like High School |publisher=The Urban Daily |date=June 8, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]],{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fergie-has-sex-and-the-citys-theme-labels-or-love-57108997.html |title=Fergie Has Sex and the City's Theme, 'Labels Or Love' |date=May 5, 2008 |location=California |publisher=Prnewswire.com |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} and [[Fantasia Barrino|Fantasia]].http://thatgrapejuice.net/2010/05/rico-love-talks-fantasias-album-wanted-show-people-seductive-side/

Love is also the CEO of Division1, a record label which partnered with [[Interscope Records]] in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/photo-galleries/rico-love-new-label-division-1-launch-party |title=Rico Love's Division 1/Universal Motown Launch Party |publisher=VIBE |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} Love has appeared as a featured artist on records with [[T.I.]],{{cite web|url=http://rapradar.com/2011/01/26/new-video-t-i-x-rico-love-lay-me-down/ |title=New Video: T.I. x Rico Love "Lay Me Down" |publisher=Rap Radar |date=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}} [[Usher (singer)|Ushe]]r,{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisrnb.com/2009/12/music-usher-feat-rico-love-shes-got-it/ |title=Music: Usher feat. @@ -20,7 +20,7 @@\n
}}
[[Major-general (United Kingdom)|Major General]] '''Sir Thompson Capper''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|sep=,|KCMG|CB|DSO}} (20 October 1863 – 27 September 1915) was a highly decorated and senior [[British Army]] officer who served with distinction in the [[Second Boer War]] and was a divisional commander during the [[First World War]]. At the [[Battle of Loos]] in 1915, Capper was shot by a sniper as he reconnoitred the front line during an assault by his division on German positions. He died the next day in a [[Casualty Clearing Station|casualty clearing station]] from wounds to both lungs; his grave is in the nearby Lillers Communal Cemetery.

-Capper was an active and vigorous soldier who had been wounded just six months before his death in an accidental grenade detonation. Shortly before this wound he had been knighted by [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] for his service in command of his division during the [[First Battle of Ypres]]. Field Marshal Sir [[John French, 1st Earl of Ypres|John French]] commented upon his death that "he was a most distinguished and capable leader and his death will be severely felt."[http://www.1914-1918.net/frenchs_ninth_despatch.htm Sir John French's Ninth Despatch], ''The Long, Long Trail''. Retrieved 9 July 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213114511/http://www.1914-1918.net/frenchs_ninth_despatch.htm |date=December 13, 2007 }} He was also a keen military historian and his collected papers are currently stored at the Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives at [[King's College London]].
+Capper was an active and vigorous soldier who had been wounded just six months before his death in an accidental grenade detonation. Shortly before this wound he had been knighted by [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] for his service in command of his division during the [[First Battle of Ypres]]. Field Marshal Sir [[John French, 1st Earl of Ypres|John French]] commented upon his death that "he was a most distinguished and capable leader and his death will be severely felt."[http://www.1914-1918.net/frenchs_ninth_despatch.htm Sir John French's Ninth Despatch], ''The Long, Long Trail''. Retrieved 9 July 2007 {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.1914-1918.net/frenchs_ninth_despatch.htm|date =20071213114511|bot=DASHBot}} He was also a keen military historian and his collected papers are currently stored at the Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives at [[King's College London]].

== Early career ==
Thompson Capper was born in October 1863 to William and Sarah Capper (''neé'' Copeland). William Capper was a civil servant with the Bengal Civil Service and Sarah was the daughter of industrialist William Copeland. Thompson and his elder brother [[John Capper|John]] were born in [[Lucknow]] but at a young age were sent to England for their education. Thompson Capper attended [[Haileybury and Imperial Service College]] and the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] before being commissioned into the [[East Lancashire Regiment]] as a junior officer in 1882.{{LondonGazette|issue=25145|startpage=4178|date=8 September 1882|accessdate=14 January 2008}}

@@ -578,7 +578,7 @@\n

There is a small number of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christians]], indigenous religions, Muslims (see [[Islam in Ecuador]]), [[Buddhist]]s and [[Bahá'í]]s. There are about 185,000 members of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church),{{cite web|url=http://www.newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/ecuador|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617143951/http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/ecuador|archivedate=17 June 2008 |title=Ecuador – LDS Newsroom |publisher=Newsroom.lds.org |accessdate=2010-06-26}}{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/ecuador|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617143951/http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/ecuador|archivedate=17 June 2008 |title=Ecuador-LDS Newsroom Country Profile |publisher=Newsroom.lds.org |accessdate=2010-06-26}} and over 80,000 [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] in the country.{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=180}}

-The "Jewish Community of Ecuador" (Comunidad Judía del Ecuador) has its seat in [[Quito]] and has approximately 300 members. Nevertheless, this number is declining because young people leave the country towards the United States of America or Israel.[http://www.cje-ec.com/inter.asp?s=2&id=e/ Ecuadorian Jewish Community] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220125124/http://www.cje-ec.com/inter.asp?s=2&id=e/ |date=February 20, 2012 }} The Community has a Jewish Center with a synagogue, a country club and a cemetery. It supports the "Albert Einstein School", where Jewish history, religion and [[Hebrew]] classes are offered. Since 2004, there has also been a [[Chabad house]] in Quito.[http://www.jabad.org.ec/texto1.php?id_submenu1=139&id_menu=36/ Beit Chabad House of Ecuador] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719133950/http://www.jabad.org.ec/texto1.php?id_submenu1=139&id_menu=36/ |date=July 19, 2011 }}
+The "Jewish Community of Ecuador" (Comunidad Judía del Ecuador) has its seat in [[Quito]] and has approximately 300 members. Nevertheless, this number is declining because young people leave the country towards the United States of America or Israel.[http://www.cje-ec.com/inter.asp?s=2&id=e/ Ecuadorian Jewish Community] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.cje-ec.com/inter.asp?s=2&id=e/ |date=20120220125124 }} The Community has a Jewish Center with a synagogue, a country club and a cemetery. It supports the "Albert Einstein School", where Jewish history, religion and [[Hebrew]] classes are offered. Since 2004, there has also been a [[Chabad house]] in Quito.[http://www.jabad.org.ec/texto1.php?id_submenu1=139&id_menu=36/ Beit Chabad House of Ecuador] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.jabad.org.ec/texto1.php?id_submenu1=139&id_menu=36/ |date=20110719133950 }}

There are very small communities in [[Cuenca (Ecuador)|Cuenca]] and [[Ambato, Ecuador|Ambato]]. The "Comunidad de Culto Israelita" reunites the Jews of [[Guayaquil]]. This community works independently from the "Jewish Community of Ecuador".{{cite web|url=http://www.congresojudio.org.ar/comunidades.asp?id=ecuador/|title=Congreso Judío Latinoamericano|trans-title=Latin American Jewish Congress|language=es|work=congresojudio.org.ar}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Jewish visitors to Ecuador can also take advantage of Jewish resources as they travel[http://travelingrabbi.com/countries/ecuador/ Traveling Rabbi Guide to Ecuador]. Travelingrabbi.com (16 August 2012). Retrieved on 2012-08-21. and keep [[kosher]] there, even in the [[Amazon Rainforest]].[http://travelingrabbi.com/2011/05/04/keeping-kosher-in-the-amazon-rainforest/ Keeping Kosher in the Amazon Rainforest]. Travelingrabbi.com (4 May 2011). Retrieved on 2012-08-21. The city has also synagogue of [[Messianic Judaism]].{{cite web|url=http://mishkanyeshua.com/|title=良い外壁塗装業者の簡単な選び方|publisher=|accessdate=29 March 2015}}

2016-11-14 05:08:47 749411915 Fluxbot GreenC bot Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/GreenC bot|GreenC bot]] ([[User talk:GreenC bot|talk]]) to last version by RobbieIanMorrison --- \n

@@ -321,7 +321,7 @@\n

For [[Scotland]], the [[Scottish Government]] has a target of generating 100% of electricity from renewables by 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-25451385 |title=BBC News - Renewable energy use at record high in Scotland |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=23 April 2014}} Renewables located in Scotland count towards both the Scottish target and to the overall target for the UK.

-Although [[renewable energy]] sources have not played a major role in the UK historically, there is potential for significant use of [[tidal power]] and [[wind energy]] (both on-shore and [[wind farms in the UK|off-shore]]) as recognised by formal UK policies, including the ''Energy White Paper'' and directives to councils[http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/planning/planningpolicyguidance/planningpolicystatements/planningpolicystatements/pps22/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423000415/http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/planning/planningpolicyguidance/planningpolicystatements/planningpolicystatements/pps22/ |date=April 23, 2008 }} in the form of PPS 22. The [[Renewables Obligation]] acts as the central mechanism for support of renewable sources of electricity in the UK, and should provide subsidies approaching one billion [[pounds sterling]] per annum by 2010. A number of other grants and smaller support mechanisms aim to support less established renewables. In addition, renewables have been exempted from the [[Climate Change Levy]] that affects all other energy sources.
+Although [[renewable energy]] sources have not played a major role in the UK historically, there is potential for significant use of [[tidal power]] and [[wind energy]] (both on-shore and [[wind farms in the UK|off-shore]]) as recognised by formal UK policies, including the ''Energy White Paper'' and directives to councils[http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/planning/planningpolicyguidance/planningpolicystatements/planningpolicystatements/pps22/ ] {{wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/planning/planningpolicyguidance/planningpolicystatements/planningpolicystatements/pps22/ |date=20080423000415 }} in the form of PPS 22. The [[Renewables Obligation]] acts as the central mechanism for support of renewable sources of electricity in the UK, and should provide subsidies approaching one billion [[pounds sterling]] per annum by 2010. A number of other grants and smaller support mechanisms aim to support less established renewables. In addition, renewables have been exempted from the [[Climate Change Levy]] that affects all other energy sources.

The amount of renewable generation added in the year 2004 was 250 [[megawatt]]s and 500 megawatts in 2005. There is also a program established for [[micro-generation]] (less than 50 KWe (kilowatt electrical) or 45 KWt (kilowatt thermal) from a low carbon source){{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/ACTS/acts2006/60019--a.htm#26 |title=The Climate Change and Sustainable Energy Act 2006 |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2014}} as well as a [[Solar cell|solar]] voltaic program. By comparison both [[Germany]] and [[Japan]] have photovoltaic (solar cell) programmes much larger than the installed base in the UK. [[Hydroelectric]] energy is not a viable option for most of the UK due to terrain and lack of force of [[river]]s.

@@ -27,192 +27,22 @@\n
Individuals with Down syndrome may have some or all of the following physical characteristics:{{cite web |url=http://healthlibrary.epnet.com/GetContent.aspx?token=94e729bf-2a24-406f-8083-f1484720ce65&chunkiid=11897 |title=Down syndrome |first=Debra |last=Wood |year=2005 |accessdate=2006-06-30}} oblique eye fissures with [[Epicanthic_fold|epicanthic skin folds]] on the inner corner of the eyes, [[muscle hypotonia]] (poor muscle tone), a flat nasal bridge, a [[Single transverse palmar crease|single palmar fold]] (also known as a simian crease), a protruding tongue (due to small oral cavity, and an enlarged tongue near the tonsils), a short neck, white spots on the [[Eye#Anatomy of the mammalian eye|iris]] known as [[Brushfield spots]],{{cite web |url=http://www.medterms.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=6570 |title=Definition of Brushfield's Spots}} excessive flexibility in joints, [[congenital heart defect]]s, excessive space between [[Hallux|large toe]] and second toe, and a single [[flexion]] furrow of the fifth finger. Most individuals with Down syndrome have [[mental retardation]] in the mild (IQ 50–70) to moderate (IQ 35–50) range,{{cite web |url=http://www.keepkidshealthy.com/welcome/conditions/downsyndrome.html |title=Keep Kids Healthy article on Down syndrome |accessedate=2006-04-10}} with scores of children having Mosaic Down syndrome (explained below) typically 10–30 points higher.{{cite web |author=Strom, C |url=http://www.mosaicdownsyndrome.com/faqs.htm |title=FAQ from Mosaic Down Syndrome Society |accessdate=2006-06-03}} In addition, individuals with Down syndrome can have serious abnormalities affecting any body system.

==Genetics==
-i have down
